subject: CBS Evening News with Katie Couric E-Mail Alert
body:

  The Early Show | CBS Evening News | 48 Hours
    | 60 Minutes | The Saturday Early Show | CBS Sunday
    Morning | Face The
    Nation 















Hi everyone,
 
Hundreds of Americans have been sickened by –
  and some have died from – contaminated spinach and peanut butter in the
  past year. A report in today’s Washington Post revealed that the FDA
  has known for years about contamination problems at the facilities that
  produced these products. Nancy Cordes will have the full story, and
  we’ll also take a look at whether the FDA has the financial ability to
  fix the problem.
 
Classes resumed today at Virginia Tech one week
  after the shooting rampage that left 32 students dead. Sharyn Alfonsi has our
  report from Blacksburg, Virginia.
 
Jim Axelrod will bring you the latest on Attorney
  General Alberto Gonzales, who has just received another vote of confidence
  from President Bush. Gonzales has promised to stay in his post as long as he
  can “continue to serve effectively.”  
 
Politics has become a popular pastime in France.
  At least 84 percent of the country’s voters cast ballots in the first
  round of presidential elections. Now, it is down to two candidates with very
  different visions for the country’s future, Sheila MacVicar will
  report.
 
Boris Yeltsin, the man who engineered the final
  collapse of the Soviet Union and brought a market economy to Russia,
  died this morning. Elizabeth Palmer will report on Yeltsin’s effect on
  democracy in Russia.
  She’ll also give you a peek into some of the lesser-known events of the
  former president’s life.
 
Back in the United States, a judge exonerated
  a man – after he had served 25 years in prison. Jerry Miller had been
  found guilty of rape, robbery, aggravated kidnapping and battery in 1981.
  Today he became the 200th prisoner exonerated due to DNA evidence,
  according to a group that works to free wrongly-convicted inmates. Byron
  Pitts will have the story.
 
The soundtrack of the young generation is hip-hop
  music – and its biggest consumers are young white males. It is an
  industry where sex and violence sell – but not everyone’s happy
  about that. Bill Whitaker will examine the debate over vulgar, violent
  lyrics. 
 
Remember those funky, flimsy 3D glasses from decades
  ago? NASA is bringing them back. It has compiled images of the sun from two
  orbiters and laid them on top of each other for a three-dimensional effect.
  Jerry Bowen will give you a look.
 
Thanks, and I hope you’ll join us.
 




Katie Couric
CouricandCo@cbs.com
